events.name: Shrink player object when player applies movement force

events.comment:
The player ejects some matter to move according to the momentum conservation law.
The momentum is the mass multiplied with the velocity.

In our case, the shrunk player momentum + the ejected matter momentum = the momentum of the player before the ejection.
playerMass(t) * playerVelocity(t) + ejectedMatterMass * ejectedMatterVelocity = playerMass(t - 1) * playerVelocity(t - 1)

The ejected matter is usually really small relatively to the player.
To simplify the formula, we make the approximation that the player doesn't change.
Which gives:
playerMass * playerVelocity(t) + ejectedMatterMass * ejectedMatterVelocity = playerMass * playerVelocity(t - 1)

Considering that the objects are cylinders, the mass is proportional to the square of the radius and we found:
ejectedMatterRadius² * ejectedMatterVelocity = - playerRadius² * (playerVelocity(t) - playerMass * playerVelocity(t - 1))
The DifficultyRatio variable allows to cheat the physic laws and eject less matter for the same speed gain (PlayerSpeedDelta).

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: Absorbus
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Logic used in the game example "Absorbus"
eventsFunctionsExtensions.description: When two objects overlap, the larger one will grow and the smaller will shrink.

eventsFunctions.description: Place an image on the object.
eventsFunctions.name: PlaceImage

eventsFunctions.description: One object obsorb the other one.
eventsFunctions.name: Absorb

events.comment:
At the beginning, the 2 objects are overlapping each other.
The eaten object radius is shrunk to make the 2 objects until the 2 circles are tangent.
As the object will grow with the matter it eats, the objects are still overlapping each other.
This creates a chain reaction frame after frame until the 2 objects converge to an almost stable state.
It avoids complex calculus to evaluate the stable state and make a free animation,
but it has the disadvantage of being frame rate dependent.

The mass conservation gives:
objectRadius(t)² + eatenRadius(t)² = objectRadius(t-1)² + eatenRadius(t-1)²

And considering that the objects are cylinders, the mass is proportional to the square of the radius:
objectRadius(t)² + eatenRadius(t)² = objectRadius(t-1)² + eatenRadius(t-1)²

Which gives:
eatenRadius(t) = sqrt(objectRadius(t-1)² - objectRadius(t)² + eatenRadius(t-1)²)

The Object absorbs some matter from the Eaten object.
The matter given to the Object has the velocity of the Eaten object.
The momentum conservation law must be used to evaluate the resultant speed to set to the Object.

The momentum conservation gives:
objectMass(t) * objectVelocity(t) = objectMass(t-1) * objectVelocity(t-1) + givenMass * eatenVelocity

And considering that the objects are cylinders, the mass is proporional to the square of the radius:
objectRadius(t)² * objectVelocity(t) = objectRadius(t-1)² * objectVelocity(t-1) + (eatenRadius(t)² - eatenRadius(t-1)²) * eatenVelocity

Which gives:
objectVelocity(t) = (objectRadius(t-1)² * objectVelocity(t-1) + (eatenRadius(t)² - eatenRadius(t-1)²) * eatenVelocity) / objectRadius(t)²

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: SineMovement
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Allow an object to move smoothly on the X and/or Y axis following a sine wave, or an ellipsis.
description: Allow an object to move smoothly on the X and/or Y axis following a sine wave, or an ellipsis.
- Floating objects, such as powerups or coins
- For circular or elliptical movement, the horizontal and vertical speed need to be the same
- For horizontal movement only, set vertical distance to 0
- For vertical movement only, set horizontal distance to 0
- For figure-8 movement, set horizontal speed to 1/2 of the vertical speed

eventsBasedBehaviors.description:
Allow an object to move smoothly on the X and/or Y axis following a sine wave.

Example uses:
- Floating pickups
- Moveable platforms
- Enemy movement

Properties:
- Center of movement, X position
- Center of movement, Y position
- Horizontal distance
- Vertical distance
- Horizontal speed
- Horizontal distance

Tips:
- For circular or elliptical movement, the horizontal and vertical speed need to be the same
- For horizontal movement, set vertical distance to 0
- For vertical movement, set horizontal distance to 0
- For figure-8 movement, set horizontal speed to 1/2 of the vertical speed.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: Westboy31
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: FlashTransitionPainter
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Behavior for shape painter allows you to paint a color all over the screen for period of time with an effect (useful for simulate flash and transition effect).
description: * __Paint effect:__ Action to paint a color all over the screen for a period of time with specific effect.
* __Flash:__ is a monochrome color appear with fade then disappear with fade out.
* __Vertical:__ is a monochrome color comes from right side then comes back.
* __Horizontal:__ is a monochrome color come from top side then comes back.
* __Circular:__ is a circle which increases from the center and narrows.
* __Paint effect ended:__ event when the paint effect ends.

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Paint all over the screen a color for a period of time.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: D8H
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: Sticker
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Make objects follow the position and rotation of the object they are stuck to.
description: This extension can be useful to:
* Delete an object with another one
An example allows to check it out ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://stick-objects)).

eventsFunctions.description: Define helper classes JavaScript code.
eventsFunctions.name: DefineHelperClasses

inlineCode: * Update the coordinates in the basisObject basis.
* It uses the basisObject coordinates from the previous frame.
* This way, the sticker can move relatively to it and still
// Save initial values to avoid calculus and rounding errors
* Copy the coordinates to use it the next frame.
* This method is also called by children to ensure
// If the behavior on the basis object has a different name,
// the objects will still follow their basis objects
// Follow parents 1st to avoid frame delays
object.setX(basisObject.getCenterXInScene() + object.getX() - object.getCenterXInScene() + deltaX * Math.cos(angle) + deltaY * Math.sin(angle));
object.setY(basisObject.getCenterYInScene() + object.getY() - object.getCenterYInScene() - deltaX * Math.sin(angle) + deltaY * Math.cos(angle));
// Unproportional dimensions changes won't work as expected
// if the object angle is not null but nothing more can be done
// because there is no full affine transformation on objects.

eventsFunctions.name: Stick

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: CameraZoom
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Allows to zoom camera on a layer with a speed (factor per second).
description: This extension allows to zoom a camera on a layer at a given speed. The zoom speed is configurable and allows a constant as well as a variable zoom speed. An anchor point can be defined, for instance, to keep what is under the cursor at the same place on screen.
- Change the zoom with an anchor point
- Zoom at a given speed and with an anchor point

eventsFunctions.description: Change the camera zoom at a given speed (in factor per second).
eventsFunctions.name: ZoomWithSpeed

parameters.longDescription: Zoom by a factor per second. 1: no effect, 2: zoom in x2 every second, 0.5: zoom out x2 every second.
parameters.name: ZoomSpeed

eventsFunctions.description: Change the camera zoom and keep an anchor point fixed on screen (instead of the center).
eventsFunctions.name: ZoomWithAnchor
eventsFunctions.sentence: Change camera zoom to: _PARAM1_ with an anchor at: _PARAM4_; _PARAM5_ (layer: _PARAM2_, camera: _PARAM3_)

events.comment:
When zooming the vector in pixels from the center to the anchor must stay the same.
It gives this system:

/ pixel_delta(t-1) = (anchor - center(t-1)) * zoom(t-1)
| pixel_delta(t) = (anchor - center(t)) * zoom(t)
\ pixel_delta(t) = pixel_delta(t-1)

where the new center can be resolved to:

center(t) = anchor + (center(t-1) - anchor) * zoom(t-1) / zoom(t)

parameters:
GetArgumentAsNumber("AnchorX")
+ (
   CameraX(GetArgumentAsString("Layer"), GetArgumentAsNumber("Camera"))
   - GetArgumentAsNumber("AnchorX")
)
* CameraZoom(GetArgumentAsString("Layer"), GetArgumentAsNumber("Camera"))
/ GetArgumentAsNumber("Zoom")

GetArgumentAsNumber("AnchorY")
+ (
   CameraY(GetArgumentAsString("Layer"), GetArgumentAsNumber("Camera"))
   - GetArgumentAsNumber("AnchorY")
)
* CameraZoom(GetArgumentAsString("Layer"), GetArgumentAsNumber("Camera"))
/ GetArgumentAsNumber("Zoom")

parameters.longDescription: 1: Initial zoom, 2: zoom in x2, 0.5: zoom out x2...
parameters.name: Zoom

eventsFunctions.description: Change the camera zoom at a given speed (in factor per second) and keep an anchor point fixed on screen (instead of the center).

eventsFunctions.name: ZoomWithSpeedAndAnchor

parameters.longDescription: Zoom by a factor per second. 1: no effect, 2: zoom in x2 every second, 0.5: zoom out x2 every second.
parameters.name: ZoomSpeed

events.comment: Keep object shaking forever (if desired)
Run once before every shake movement

events.name: Correct for drift and reset drift tracking variables

events.comment: Move to correct any drift from previous shake
Reset drift detection variables
Calculate Position Shake
PositionDisplacement = (DesiredDuration - RunningTimer) / DesiredDuration * Amplitude * [-1 or 1]
Make initial shake NOT random so users can set a direction for a one-shake effect
After initial shake pick a random direction
Calculate Rotation (angle) shake
Every "even" shake, rotate clockwise
AngleDisplacement = (DesiredDuration - RunningTimer) / DesiredDuration * Amplitude
Every "odd" shake, rotate counter-clockwise
AngleDisplacement = (DesiredDuration - RunningTimer) / DesiredDuration * Amplitude
Save that initial shake has been processed
Calculate the fraction of shake that occured during this frame
Increase change for the first half of the shake (move away from original values)
Change position
Save movement to calculate drift
Change angle
Save movement to calculate drift
Decrease change the second half of the shake (return to original position)
Change position
Save movement to calculate drift
Change angle
Save movement to calculate drift
Stop shaking when the duration has been reached (or if the stop shaking function was called)

events.name: Correct for drift and reset drift tracking variables

events.comment: Move to correct any drift from previous shake
Reset drift detection variables

parameters.longDescription: Use a negative number to make the single-shake move in the opposite direction.
parameters.name: PowerY

parameters.description: Amplitude of angle rotation shake (in degrees)  (For example: 5)
parameters.name: PowerAngle

parameters.description: Amplitude of scale shake (in percent change)  (For example: 5)
parameters.name: PowerScale

parameters.description: Amount of time between shakes (in seconds) (Default: 0.08)
parameters.longDescription: For a single-shake effect, set it to the same value as "Duration".
parameters.name: TimeBetweenShakes

events.comment: Keep object shaking forever (if desired)
Run once before every shake movement

events.name: Correct for drift and reset drift tracking variables

events.comment: Move to correct any drift from previous shake
Reset drift detection variables
Calculate Position Shake
PositionDisplacement = (DesiredDuration - RunningTimer) / DesiredDuration * Amplitude * [-1 or 1]
Make initial shake NOT random so users can set a direction for a one-shake effect
After initial shake pick a random direction
Calculate Rotation (angle) shake
Every "even" shake, rotate clockwise
AngleDisplacement = (DesiredDuration - RunningTimer) / DesiredDuration * Amplitude
Every "odd" shake, rotate counter-clockwise
AngleDisplacement = (DesiredDuration - RunningTimer) / DesiredDuration * Amplitude
Calculate Scale shake
Calculate object scale displacement, with linear decay over time
ScaleDisplacement = (DesiredDuration - RunningTimer) / DesiredDuration * Amplitude *  1/100
Every even shake, increase scale
Every "odd" shake, decrease scale
ScaleDisplacement = -1 * (DesiredDuration - RunningTimer) / DesiredDuration * Amplitude *  1/100
Save that initial shake has been processed
Calculate the fraction of shake that occured during this frame
Increase change for the first half of the shake (move away from original values)
Change position
Save movement to calculate drift
Change angle
Save movement to calculate drift
Change scale
Save movement to calculate drift
Decrease change the second half of the shake (return to original position)
Change position
Save movement to calculate drift
Change angle
Save movement to calculate drift
Change scale
Save movement to calculate drift
Stop shaking when the duration has been reached (or if the stop shaking function was called)

events.name: Correct for drift and reset drift tracking variables

events.comment: Move to correct any drift from previous shake
Reset drift detection variables

eventsFunctions.description: Stop shaking an object.
eventsFunctions.name: StopShaking

eventsFunctions.fullName: Check if an object is shaking
eventsFunctions.name: IsShaking

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: add_, @Jurfix
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: ExtendedMath
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Additional math functions and constants as expressions and conditions.
description: - Coordinates conversion for polar and isometric systems
- ToFixedString: Formats a number into a string with the specified number of decimal places
- ToFixed: (Deprecated) Formats a number to use the specified number of decimal places
- IsEven: Check if the number is even (divisible by 2)
- Deprecated ToFixed() because it does not show any trailing zeros for whole numbers. Prefer using ToFixedString() to set values in text objects.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: 4ian
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: Parallax
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Behaviors to animate Tiled Sprite objects in the background, following the camera with a parallax effect.
description: Behaviors to animate Tiled Sprite objects in the background, following the camera with a parallax effect.
- The parallax now starts with an offset of 0.

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Move the image of a Tiled Sprite to follow the camera horizontally with a parallax effect. After adding this to an object, put the object on a layer that is not moving, behind the layer that is followed (for example, a layer called "Background").
eventsBasedBehaviors.fullName: Horizontal Parallax for a Tiled Sprite
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: HorizontalTiledSpriteParallax

events.comment:
- The left side of the camera is used to have the left side of the image at X = 0 in the scene.
  This also allows the image to keep the same location when the window ratio changes.

- The camera left side is calculated for a zoom of 1 instead of using CameraBorderLeft() that use the current zoom.
  It allows the image to keep the same location when the zoom change.

(CameraCenterX(FollowedLayer) - CameraWidth(FollowedLayer) / 2 * CameraZoom(FollowedLayer)) * ParallaxFactor

When a zoom changes, the object size in the scene also change to cover the screen.
This part of the formula takes this into account:

(CameraZoom(Object.Layer()) - 1) * CameraWidth(Object.Layer()) / 2

propertyDescriptors.label: Parallax factor (speed for the parallax, usually between 0 and 1)
propertyDescriptors.name: ParallaxFactor

propertyDescriptors.label: Layer to be followed (leave empty for the base layer)
propertyDescriptors.name: FollowedLayer

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Move the image of a Tiled Sprite to follow the camera vertically with a parallax effect. After adding this to an object, put the object on a layer that is not moving, behind the layer that is followed (for example, a layer called "Background").
eventsBasedBehaviors.fullName: Vertical Parallax for a Tiled Sprite
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: VerticalTiledSpriteParallax

events.comment: See the comment in the other behavior for an explanation of this formula.

propertyDescriptors.label: Parallax factor (speed for the parallax, usually between 0 and 1)
propertyDescriptors.name: ParallaxFactor

propertyDescriptors.label: Layer to be followed (leave empty for the base layer)
propertyDescriptors.name: FollowedLayer

propertyDescriptors.label: Offset on Y axis
propertyDescriptors.name: OffsetY
